name: ethanol, 2-[(2-amino-9h-purin-9-yl)methoxy]-
Reason: The key structural components influencing the melting point of a compound like 2-[(2-amino-9H-purin-9-yl)methoxy]ethanol include the purine base and the glycol ether side chain. The purine base is a bicyclic aromatic heterocycle with a high degree of resonance stabilization which typically raises melting points given the planarity and the ability to stack in the solid state (+100). The presence of both amino and ether functional groups (-OH and -OCH2CH2OH) introduces hydrogen-bonding capabilities, which significantly increase melting points compared to non-hydrogen-bonding groups (+30 each for hydrogen bonding, -5 for increased molecular flexibility due to the ethoxy chain's rotational freedom). The purine core of the molecule contributes the most to increased melting points, while the additional functional groups modify this base value.

name: ethanol, 2-[(2-amino-9h-purin-9-yl)methoxy]-
Reason: The compound 2-[(2-amino-9H-purin-9-yl)methoxy]ethanol has several functional groups that influence its melting point. The purine base, being a bicyclic aromatic heterocycle, contributes significantly to the melting point due to the resonance stabilization and stacking ability (+100). Each of the amino and ether groups can form hydrogen bonds, which generally elevate the melting point; however, the flexibility introduced by the ethoxy chain allows some rotational freedom which may slightly reduce the melting point (-5). While hydrogen bonding typically raises melting points by around +30 for each group capable of forming such bonds, in this case, there are three sites (two from the amino group and one from the ether group) that can participate in hydrogen bonding, so we need to quantify the effect threefold (+90). Combining these effects with a baseline similar to adenine which has a melting point around 360 to 365 °C due to the purine base, we expect the additional groups to modify this value.
Prediction: 360 (adenine base) + 100 (purine stabilization and stacking) + 90 (three hydrogen bonding sites) - 5 (rotational freedom of the ethoxy chain) = 545 °C

name: ethanol, 2-[(2-amino-9h-purin-9-yl)methoxy]-
Reason: The target compound is a derivative of adenine (a purine base) with two additional ethoxy groups. The basic adenine unit which consists of a fused imidazole and pyrimidine ring has a relatively high melting point as a consequence of its planar aromatic structure and hydrogen-bonding capabilities. The presence of nitrogen atoms in the aromatic rings contributes to a higher melting point due to their ability to participate in hydrogen bonding. An unsubstituted adenine has a melting point of around 360°C. Each ethoxy group (-OCH2CH3) contributes to a lower melting point due to the introduction of aliphatic character and increase in conformational flexibility. We can estimate the effect of each ethoxy group to be around -50°C, as aliphatic ethers generally decrease the melting point when added to rigid aromatic systems.

name: ethanol, 2-[(2-amino-9h-purin-9-yl)methoxy]-
Reason: The target compound is a derivative of adenine (a purine base) with two additional ethoxy groups. The basic adenine unit which consists of a fused imidazole and pyrimidine ring has a relatively high melting point due to its planar aromatic structure and extensive hydrogen-bonding capabilities. An unsubstituted adenine has a melting point of around 360°C. Each ethoxy group (-OCH2CH3) contributes to a lower melting point due to the introduction of aliphatic character and increase in conformational flexibility. One ethoxy group could conceivably lower the melting point by approximately -85.5°C, being derived from halving the difference between the predicted melting point and that of unsubstituted adenine. This effect is consistent with the principle that aliphatic ethers generally decrease the melting point when added to a rigid aromatic system.
